conversation.message: Dear School_D Admissions, I’m Student_C and School_D is my first-choice school. I’m applying because I strongly value your academic environment and would be honored to join your community. If admitted, I will accept and commit to enrolling. Thank you for your consideration.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_D, and I have relatively strong priority there (2nd, behind Student_A). Applying immediately maximizes my chance to secure my first choice before Student_A potentially takes the only seat. Even if Student_A also applies, an early application is still my best move given quotas are 1 everywhere and my next-best options (School_C, School_E) have weaker priority positions for me.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_C,

Thank you for your application and for naming School_D as your first choice. We appreciate your commitment and are pleased to offer you admission to School_D.

We look forward to welcoming you to our community.

Sincerely,
School_D Admissions
conversation.thought: Student_C is 2nd on School_D’s true priority list (behind Student_A) and has applied with a clear commitment to enroll. In this round, only Student_C contacted us, and accepting now secures a very high-priority match within our quota of 1. While Student_A is our top choice, there is no guarantee Student_A will apply to School_D (they rank School_D 3rd after School_E and School_B), so waiting risks ending unmatched or matching with a lower-priority student. Given Student_C’s first-choice status and high rank on our list, accepting is optimal.

conversation.message: Dear School_E Admissions, I’m Student_D and I’m formally applying because School_E is my first choice. Although School_E ranks me 4th (behind Student_E, Student_B, Student_A), applying immediately is still optimal because it is my highest preference and there is a chance higher-priority students commit elsewhere. A direct, motivated application may help if the school has discretion in close decisions and also signals strong commitment early.

In this round I received [APPLY] from Student_D, Student_A, Student_E, and Student_B. Since I can accept only one, I should accept the highest-ranked applicant available now, which is Student_E, and reject lower-ranked applicants. Student_D is 4th on my list and I have higher-priority candidates actively applying, so accepting Student_D would block a better match. Therefore I reject Student_D.
